math/abs.name: math/abs
math/abs.detaildescription:
The action calculates $ \lvert x_i \rvert $ for all arguments 
[A|B|C]=math/abs(-1,-5,3);

math/acos.name: math/acos
math/acos.detaildescription:
The action calculates $ acos( x_i ) $ for all arguments, the return value is in $ [0, \pi) $, the arguments must be in radians. 
[A|B|C]=math/acos(-1,-5,3);

storage/add.name: storage/add
storage/add.briefdescription: adds or overwrites an element in the agent-storage.
storage/add.detaildescription:
The action adds all tuples into the storage, the arguments are tuples of a name and any value, if the key is forbidden or the arguments number is odd, the action fails 
storage/add("foo",X,"bar",Y);

graph/addedge.name: graph/addedge
graph/addedge.briefdescription: adds an edge to the graph.
graph/addedge.detaildescription:
The action adds to each graph the pair of vertices, so the first two arguments are the vertices, all other arguments are graphs, the action fails on wrong input 
graph/addedge(Edge,StartVertex,EndVertex,Graph1,Graph2,Graph3);

agent/addplan.name: agent/addplan
agent/addplan.briefdescription: adds a plan to the plan-base.
agent/addplan.detaildescription:
The actions adds all arguments which are plans to the plan-base of the current agent, the action never fails 
agent/addplan(Plan1,Plan2,[Plan3,[Plan4]]);

math/statistic/addstatisticvalue.name: math/statistic/addstatisticvalue
math/statistic/addstatisticvalue.briefdescription: action to push a values to the statistic object.
math/statistic/addstatisticvalue.detaildescription:
The actions adds the given argument number values to each statistic objects within the arguments, the ordering of values and statistic object is free, each value will be added to each statistic object and the action fails on a wrong input, only number and statistic objects are allowed 
math/statistic/addstatisticvalue(StatisticObject1,[1,2,3,StatisticObject2],1,5,8,StatisticObject3);

graph/addvertex.name: graph/addvertex
graph/addvertex.briefdescription: adds a vertex to the graph.
graph/addvertex.detaildescription:
The action adds a vertex to the graph, so the first argument is the vertex and all other arguments are graphs, the action never fails 
graph/addvertex(Value,Graph1,[Graph2,[Graph3]]);

graph/adjacencymatrix.name: graph/adjacencymatrix
graph/adjacencymatrix.briefdescription: creates from a graph the adjacency matrix.
note: the cost-map does not need an entry for each edge non-existing edges have got on default zero costs with 1

bool/allmatch.name: bool/allmatch
bool/allmatch.briefdescription: checks all elements are equal to the first argument.
bool/allmatch.detaildescription:
The actions checks the first argument to all other if this matchs for equality, the action never fails 
AllEqual=generic/bool/anymatch("thisisthetest",123,"thisisthetest",["hello",234]);
note: on number arguments not the value must equal, also the type (double / integral) must be equal, so keep in mind, that you use the correct number type on the argument input

math/bit/matrix/and.name: math/bit/matrix/and
math/bit/matrix/and.briefdescription: performs the logical and operation to all bit matrices.
math/bit/matrix/and.detaildescription:
The action runs the logical and operator, the first argument is the bit matrix, that is combined with all other bit matrices, so $ m_i = m_i \text{ && } m_1 $ is performed, the action never fails 
math/bit/matrix/and(Matrix,Matrix1,Matrix2);

bool/and.name: bool/and
bool/and.briefdescription: combines all arguments to a single result with the and-operator.
bool/and.detaildescription:
This action uses the logical cpnjunction to combine all logical arguments in a single result, the action never fails 
R=generic/bool/and(Logical1,[Logical2,Logical3],Logical4);

math/bit/vector/and.name: math/bit/vector/and
math/bit/vector/and.briefdescription: performs the logical and operation to all bit vectors.
math/bit/vector/and.detaildescription:
The action runs the logical and operator, the first argument is the bit vector, that is combined with all other bit vectors, so $ v_i = v_i \text{ && } v_1 $ is performed, the action never fails 
math/bit/vector/and(Vector,Vector1,Vector2);

bool/anymatch.name: bool/anymatch
bool/anymatch.briefdescription: checks any elements are equal to the first argument.
bool/anymatch.detaildescription:
The actions checks the first argument to all other if any matchs for equality, the action never fails 
AnyEqual=generic/bool/anymatch("thisisthetest",123,"thisisthetest",["hello",234]);
note: on number arguments not the value must equal, also the type (double / integral) must be equal, so keep in mind, that you use the correct number type on the argument input

datetime/applydays.name: datetime/applydays
datetime/applydays.briefdescription: subtract or adds a number of days.
datetime/applydays.detaildescription:
The action adds / subtracts a number of days to the date-time objects, the first argument is a string with minus or plus, the second argument the number and all other arguments are date-time objects, the action returns the modified date-time objects, the action never fails 
[O1|O2]=datetime/applydays("minus|plus"3,DateTime1,DateTime2);

datetime/applyhours.name: datetime/applyhours
datetime/applyhours.briefdescription: subtract or adds a number of hours.
datetime/applyhours.detaildescription:
The action adds / subtracts a number of hours to the date-time objects, the first argument is a string with minus or plus, the second argument the number and all other arguments are date-time objects, the action returns the modified date-time objects, the action never fails 
[O1|O2]=datetime/applyhours("minus|plus"6,DateTime1,DateTime2);

datetime/applyminutes.name: datetime/applyminutes
datetime/applyminutes.briefdescription: subtract or adds a number of minutes.
datetime/applyminutes.detaildescription:
The action adds / subtracts a number of minutes to the date-time objects, the first argument is a string with minus or plus, the second argument the number and all other arguments are date-time objects, the action returns the modified date-time objects, the action never fails 
[O1|O2]=datetime/applyminutes("minus|plus"6,DateTime1,DateTime2);

datetime/applymonths.name: datetime/applymonths
datetime/applymonths.briefdescription: subtract or adds a number of months.
datetime/applymonths.detaildescription:
The action adds / subtracts a number of months to the date-time objects, the first argument is a string with minus or plus, the second argument the number and all other arguments are date-time objects, the action returns the modified date-time objects, the action never fails 
[O1|O2]=datetime/applymonths("minus|plus"6,DateTime1,DateTime2);

datetime/applynanoseconds.name: datetime/applynanoseconds
datetime/applynanoseconds.briefdescription: subtract or adds a number of nano-seconds.
datetime/applynanoseconds.detaildescription:
The action adds / subtracts a number of nano-seconds to the date-time objects, the first argument is a string with minus or plus, the second argument the number and all other arguments are date-time objects, the action returns the modified date-time objects, the action never fails 
[O1|O2]=datetime/applynanoseconds("minus|plus"6,DateTime1,DateTime2);

datetime/applyseconds.name: datetime/applyseconds
datetime/applyseconds.briefdescription: subtract or adds a number of seconds.
datetime/applyseconds.detaildescription:
The action adds / subtracts a number of seconds to the date-time objects, the first argument is a string with minus or plus, the second argument the number and all other arguments are date-time objects, the action returns the modified date-time objects, the action never fails 
[O1|O2]=datetime/applyseconds("minus|plus"6,DateTime1,DateTime2);

datetime/applyyears.name: datetime/applyyears
datetime/applyyears.briefdescription: subtract or adds a number of years.
datetime/applyyears.detaildescription:
The action adds / subtracts a number of years to the date-time objects, the first argument is a string with minus or plus, the second argument the number and all other arguments are date-time objects, the action returns the modified date-time objects, the action never fails 
[O1|O2]=datetime/applyyears("minus|plus"3,DateTime1,DateTime2);

math/asin.name: math/asin
math/asin.detaildescription:
The action calculates $ asin( x_i ) $ for all arguments, the return value is in $ [0, \pi) $, the arguments must be in radians. 
[A|B|C]=math/asin(-1,-5,3);

collection/multimap/asmap.name: collection/multimap/asmap

math/blas/matrix/assign.name: math/blas/matrix/assign
math/blas/matrix/assign.briefdescription: assigns a value or matrix to all elements.

math/blas/vector/assign.name: math/blas/vector/assign
math/blas/vector/assign.briefdescription: assigns a value or vector to all elements.

math/atan.name: math/atan
math/atan.detaildescription:
The action calculates $ atan( x_i ) $ for all arguments, the return value is in $ [0, \pi) $, the arguments must be in radians. 
[A|B|C]=math/atan(-1,-5,3);

math/average.name: math/average
math/average.detaildescription:
The action calculates $ \frac{1}{i} \sum_{i} x_i $ over all arguments, action fails never, but can throw a runtime exception 
A=math/average(1,3,9,[10,[11,12]]);

string/base64decode.name: string/base64decode
string/base64decode.briefdescription: action to decodes a string with Base64.
string/base64decode.detaildescription:
Creates from each string argument, which is based64 encoded the decoded string version, the action never fails 
[A|B]=generic/string/base64decode("aGVsbG8=","QWdlbnRTcGVhayhMKysp");

string/base64encode.name: string/base64encode
string/base64encode.briefdescription: action to encodes a string with Base64.
string/base64encode.detaildescription:
Creates from each string argument the base64 encoded version, the action fails on encoding errors 
[A|B]=generic/string/base64encode("Hello","AgentSpeak(L++)");

agent/belieflist.name: agent/belieflist
agent/belieflist.briefdescription: returns a list of all belief literals.
agent/belieflist.detaildescription:
The action creates a list of literals, the arguments are optional, the first argument is a boolean for the negation definition, the second argument is the belief functor, if no arguments are give, the full belieflist is returned 
L=agent/belieflist(true,"path/subpath/literalfunctor");

math/binomial.name: math/binomial
math/binomial.detaildescription:
Calcluates $ \binom{n}{k} $, where n is the first argument and k the second of each given input tupel, the action fails never 
[B1|B2]=math/binomial(49,6,30,5);

math/bit/matrix/boolvalue.name: math/bit/matrix/boolvalue
math/bit/matrix/boolvalue.briefdescription: returns for the index tuple a boolean value.
math/bit/matrix/boolvalue.detaildescription:
The action returns for the first argument, which is a bit matrix, all boolean values for all given index tuples (row / column), the action fail on incorrect input 
[B1|B2]=math/bit/matrix/boolvalue(BitMatrix,1,2,[3,5]);

math/bit/vector/boolvalue.name: math/bit/vector/boolvalue
math/bit/vector/boolvalue.briefdescription: returns for the index a boolean value.
math/bit/vector/boolvalue.detaildescription:
The action returns for the first argument, which is a bit vector, all boolean values for all given index values, the action never fails 
[B1|B2|B3]=math/bit/vector/boolvalue(BitVector,1,[3,5]);

datetime/build.name: datetime/build
datetime/build.briefdescription: builds a date-time object from elements.
datetime/build.detaildescription:
The actions creates form an eight-tuple a date-time object and never fails, the seventh argument within the tuple is the time-zone, which can be set to empty or "current", so the system-default zone is used 
O1=datetime/build(Year,Month,Day,Hour,Minutes,Second,NanoSeconds,"current");

math/ceil.name: math/ceil
math/ceil.detaildescription:
Ceils any argument values with $ \lceil x_i \rceil $ and returns all values, the action never fails 
[A|B|C]=math/ceil(1.3,2.8,9.7);

storage/clear.name: storage/clear
storage/clear.briefdescription: removes all elements of the storage.
storage/clear.detaildescription:
The action removes all elements from the storage except the elements wich are forbidden, the action, never fails 
storage/clear();

math/bit/vector/clear.name: math/bit/vector/clear
math/bit/vector/clear.briefdescription: sets the indexed bit to false within the bit vector.
math/bit/vector/clear.detaildescription:
The action gets bit vectors and index positions and in each bit vector the given bit positions are set to false, the action never fails 
math/bit/vector/clear(BitVector1,0,1,BitVector2,[3,5]);

agent/clearbeliefbase.name: agent/clearbeliefbase
agent/clearbeliefbase.briefdescription: clears all elements from the beliefbase.
agent/clearbeliefbase.detaildescription:
The action clear th beliefbase, the arguments are optional and can be string paths to beliefbases 
agent/clearbeliefbase("env","foo");

math/statistic/clearstatistic.name: math/statistic/clearstatistic
math/statistic/clearstatistic.detaildescription:
The actions clears statistic objects, so all arguments must be statistic objects 
math/statistic/clearstatistic(Statistic1,[Statistic2,[Statistic3]]);

math/bit/matrix/column.name: math/bit/matrix/column
math/bit/matrix/column.briefdescription: returns a single column of a bit matrix.
math/bit/matrix/column.detaildescription:
The action returns a column of a bit matrix as vector, the first argument is the index of the column, all other a matrix objects, the action never fails 
[V1|V2]=math/bit/matrix/column(3,Matrix1,[Matrix2]);

math/blas/matrix/column.name: math/blas/matrix/column
math/blas/matrix/column.briefdescription: returns a single column of a matrix.
math/blas/matrix/column.detaildescription:
The action returns a column of a matrix as vector, the first argument is the index of the column, all other a matrix objects, the action never fails 
[V1|V2]=math/blas/matrix/column(3,Matrix1,[Matrix2]);

math/bit/matrix/columns.name: math/bit/matrix/columns
math/bit/matrix/columns.briefdescription: returns the column number of a bit matrix.
math/bit/matrix/columns.detaildescription:
Reads the column number of each input matrix and returns the value, the action never fails. 
[C1|C2]=math/bit/matrix/columns(M1,M2);

math/blas/matrix/columns.name: math/blas/matrix/columns
math/blas/matrix/columns.briefdescription: returns the column number of a matrix.
math/blas/matrix/columns.detaildescription:
Reads the column number of each input matrix and returns the value, the action never fails. 
[C1|C2]=math/blas/matrix/columns(M1,M2);

collection/list/complement.name: collection/list/complement
collection/list/complement.detaildescription:
The action uses two input arguments $ \mathbb{A} $ and $ \mathbb{B} $ and returns a list of all elements which contains $ \mathbb{A} \setminus \mathbb{B} $, the action fails never 
L=collection/list/complement([1,2,3],[3,4,5]);

string/concat.name: string/concat
string/concat.briefdescription: action to concat / join all strings.
string/concat.detaildescription:
All string arguments will be join to a single result, the action never fails 
S=generic/string/concat("A","B","C");

math/blas/matrix/condition.name: math/blas/matrix/condition
math/blas/matrix/condition.briefdescription: returns the condition of a matrix.
math/blas/matrix/condition.detaildescription:
Calculates for each input matrix the condition number and returns the value, the action never fails 
[C1|C2]=math/blas/matrix/condition(M1,M2);

string/contains.name: string/contains
string/contains.briefdescription: action to check string for containing another string.
string/contains.detaildescription:
The action checks the first string argument if it contains all other arguments, but it returns the boolean result for each argument, the action never fails 
[L1|L2]=generic/string/contains("thisisalongstring","long","string");

graph/containsedge.name: graph/containsedge
graph/containsedge.briefdescription: check if a graph contains an edge.
graph/containsedge.detaildescription:
The action checks for the first argument, if each other graph argument contains the first item as an edge, the action fails on wrong input 
[B1|B2]=graph/containsedge(Element,Graph1,Graph2);

graph/containsvertex.name: graph/containsvertex
graph/containsvertex.briefdescription: check if a graph contains a vertex.
graph/containsvertex.detaildescription:
The action checks for the first argument, if each other graph argument contains the first item as an vertex, the action fails on wrong input 
[B1|B2]=graph/containsvertex(Element,Graph1,Graph2);

math/bit/matrix/copy.name: math/bit/matrix/copy
math/bit/matrix/copy.briefdescription: returns a copy of the matrix.
math/bit/matrix/copy.detaildescription:
All input matrix objects will be copied and returned, the action never fails 
[A|B]=math/bit/matrix/copy(Matrix1,Matrix2);

math/bit/vector/copy.name: math/bit/vector/copy
math/bit/vector/copy.briefdescription: returns a copy of the vector.
math/bit/vector/copy.detaildescription:
All input vector objects will be copied and returned, the action never fails 
[A|B]=math/bit/vector/copy(Vector1,Vector2);

math/blas/matrix/copy.name: math/blas/matrix/copy
math/blas/matrix/copy.briefdescription: returns a copy of the matrix.
math/blas/matrix/copy.detaildescription:
All input matrix object will be copied and returned, the action never fails 
[A|B]=math/blas/matrix/copy(Matrix1,Matrix2);

math/blas/vector/copy.name: math/blas/vector/copy
math/blas/vector/copy.briefdescription: returns a copy of the vector.
math/blas/vector/copy.detaildescription:
All input vector object will be copied and returned, the action never fails 
[A|B]=math/blas/vector/copy(Vector1,Vector2);

math/cos.name: math/cos
math/cos.detaildescription:
The action calculates $ cos( x_i ) $ for each argument in radians and returns the values 
[A|B]=math/cos(3,4);

math/cosh.name: math/cosh
math/cosh.detaildescription:
The action calculates for all arguments $ cosh( x_i ) $ and fails never, the arguments must be in radians. 
[A|B]=math/cosh(3,4);

bool/countfalse.name: bool/countfalse
bool/countfalse.briefdescription: count the number of false values.
bool/countfalse.detaildescription:
This action counts the number of false values, the action never fails 
R=generic/bool/countfalse(Logical1,[Logical2,Logical3],Logical4);

bool/counttrue.name: bool/counttrue
bool/counttrue.briefdescription: counts the number of true values.
bool/counttrue.detaildescription:
This actioncounts the number of true values and fails never 
C=generic/bool/counttrue(Logical1,[Logical2,Logical3],Logical4);

math/interpolate/create.name: math/interpolate/create
math/interpolate/create.briefdescription: action to create a spline interpolation.
math/interpolate/create.detaildescription:
The action creates an interpolation object, the first is the type of interpolation (akima, divideddifference, linear, loess, neville), and all other number arguments are the the base values for interpolation, the first $ \frac{n}{2} $ are x-values the other $ \frac{n}{2} $ values are the y-values 
PI=math/interpolate/create("akima|divideddifference|linear|loess|neville",[-5,1,2,8,14],[7,3,7,4,8]);

math/linearprogram/create.name: math/linearprogram/create
math/linearprogram/create.briefdescription: action to create a linear program.
math/linearprogram/create.detaildescription:
This action creates the linear program with the objective functions $ \left( \sum_{i=1} c_i \cdot x_i \right) + d $, the first $ n-1 $ arguments are the $ c_i $ values (coefficients) and the last argument is the $ d $ value (constant) of the objective function, the action is never failing 
LP=math/linearprogram/create(1,2,[3,[4,5]],10);

datetime/create.name: datetime/create
datetime/create.detaildescription:
The action returns a date-time object based on the string input arguments, the action parses the string if the string is empty or "now" the current date-time will returned, the action never fails 
[O1|O2]=datetime/create("now","2007-12-03T10:15:30+01:00[Europe/Paris]");

math/bit/matrix/create.name: math/bit/matrix/create
math/bit/matrix/create.detaildescription:
All tuple arguments are defined the size of bit matrix, so for each input tuple argument a bit matrix will be created and returned, the action never fails 
[A|B]=math/bit/matrix/create(3,2,[1,12]);

math/bit/vector/create.name: math/bit/vector/create
math/bit/vector/create.detaildescription:
All arguments are defined the size of bit vectors, so for each input argument a bit vector will be created and returned, the action never fails 
[A|B|C|D]=math/bit/vector/create(3,[2,[1,12]]);

collection/map/create.name: collection/map/create
collection/map/create.detaildescription:
Returns an empty hashmap (key-value pair) and optional arguments must be even and it will create a key-value structure, the action fails on an odd number of arguments except zero only 
M=collection/map/create();

math/blas/matrix/create.name: math/blas/matrix/create
math/blas/matrix/create.detaildescription:
The action creates densore or sparse matrix objects, the last object is a string with dense or sparse, all other arguments are tuples of row and column size. 
[M1|M2]=math/blas/matrix/create(2,2,[3,2],"dense|sparse");

collection/multimap/create.name: collection/multimap/create

collection/list/create.name: collection/list/create

graph/create.name: graph/create
graph/create.detaildescription:
The action create a graph data structure with nodes and edges, arguments are strings with the name of the graph type ( SPARSE | SPARSEMULTI | DIRECTEDSPARSE | DIRECTEDSPARSEMULTI | UNDIRECTEDSPARSE | UNDIRECTEDSPARSEMULTI ) on a wrong name, a sparse graph is created, the action never fails 
[G1|G2]=graph/create("sparse","directedsparse");

collection/tuple/create.name: collection/tuple/create
collection/tuple/create.briefdescription: creates a tuple of two elements.
collection/tuple/create.detaildescription:
The number of arguments must be even and each two elements will be combined into a tupel and never fails 
[A|B]=collection/tupel/create("A","1",["B","2"]);

math/blas/vector/create.name: math/blas/vector/create
math/blas/vector/create.detaildescription:
The action creates a vector, the first $ n-1 $ arguments are the size of the vector, the last argument defines as string a dense or sparse vector (default is dense) and the action never fails 
[A|B|C]=math/blas/vector/create(3,2,1,"dense|sparse");

math/statistic/createdistribution.name: math/statistic/createdistribution
math/statistic/createdistribution.detaildescription:
The action creates a distribution objects, with an individual pseudo-random generator and different distribution paramter, the action never fails, the following distributions are supported with the following number of numeric arguments
  • beta distribution with 2 arguments ( $ \alpha $ and $ \beta $)
  • cauchy distribution with 2 arguments (media and scale)
  • chi-square distribution with 1 argument (degree off freedom)
  • exponential distribution with 1 argument (mean)
  • f distribution with 2 arguments (degrees of freedom, denominator degrees of freedom)
  • gamma distribution with 2 arguments (shape and scale)
  • gumble distribution with 2 arguments ( $ \mu $ and $ \beta $)
  • laplace distirbution with 2 arguments ( $ \mu $ and $ \beta $)
  • levy distirbution with 2 arguments ( $ \mu $ and $ c $)
  • logistic distirbution with 2 arguments ( $ \mu $ and $ s $)
  • lognormal distirbution with 2 arguments (scale and shape)
  • nakagami distribution with 2 arguments ( $ \mu $ and $ \omega $)
  • normal distribution with 2 arguments (expected value, variance)
  • pareto distribution with 2 arguments (scale and shape)
  • t distribution with 1 argument (degrees of freedom)
  • triangular distribution with 3 arguments (a, b, c)
  • uniform distribution with 2 arguments (lower and upper)
  • weibull distribution with 2 arguments ( $ \alpha $ and $ \beta $)
The following pseudo-random number generators are supported:
  • mersennetwister (default)
  • synchronizedmersennetwister
  • isaac
  • synchronizedisaac
  • internal
  • synchronizedinternal
  • well512a
  • synchronizedwell512a
  • well1024a
  • synchronizedwell1024a
  • well19937a
  • synchronizedwell19937a
  • well19937c
  • synchronizedwell19937c
  • well4449a
  • synchronizedwell4449a
  • well44497b
  • synchronizedwell44497b
[D1|D2]=math/statistic/createdistribution("normal",20,10,["beta","isaac",[8,12]]);

crypto/createkey.name: crypto/createkey
crypto/createkey.briefdescription: creates an encrypting / decrypting key pair.
crypto/createkey.detaildescription:
The argument is a string with the cryptographic algorithm AES, DES or RSA and the action return a key pair, the action fails if the key cannot generated 
[PublicKey,PrivateKey]=cypto/createkey("AES|DES|RSA");
note: The private key is set on RSA algorithm only

generic/type/createliteral.name: generic/type/createliteral
generic/type/createliteral.briefdescription: creates a literal by the input data.
generic/type/createliteral.detaildescription:
The action create a literal, so the first argument is a string with the literal functor all other arguments will be used for the literal values 
L=generic/type/createliteral("literal/functor/with/path",123,"value");

math/statistic/createstatistic.name: math/statistic/createstatistic
math/statistic/createstatistic.detaildescription:
The action creates statistic objects to collect data, each argument must be a string with "summary" or "descriptive" for a summary or descriptive statistic object, on no arguments a summary statistic object is created, the action never fails 
[S1|S2]=math/statistic/createstaistic("summary",["descriptive"]);

agent/cycletime.name: agent/cycletime
agent/cycletime.detaildescription:
The action returns the time between the last cycle and the current time in nanoseconds and fails never 
T=agent/cycletime();

datetime/date.name: datetime/date
datetime/date.briefdescription: action for getting the current date.
datetime/date.detaildescription:
The action returns the date elements of a parsed string or date-time object, if the string is empty or "now" the current date-time is used, the action fails on wrong input 
[Year|Month|Day|DayOfWeek|DayOfYear]=datetime/date("now");

datetime/daysbetween.name: datetime/daysbetween
datetime/daysbetween.briefdescription: returns the days between two dates.
datetime/daysbetween.detaildescription:
The actions returns the number of days between two date-time objects, the action never fails 
[D1|D2]=datetime/daysbetween(DateTime1,DateTime2,DateTime3,DateTime4);

crypto/decrypt.name: crypto/decrypt
crypto/decrypt.detaildescription:
The actions decrypts data by the key, that is set on the first argument, all other arguments are datasets for encrypting, the actions returns all drcrypted datasets back and fails if a dataset cannot be decrypted 
[DecyptData1|DecyptData2|DecyptData3]=crypto/decrypt(Key,Dataset1,Dataset2,Dataset3);

graph/degree.name: graph/degree
graph/degree.briefdescription: returns the degree of a vertex.
graph/degree.detaildescription:
The action returns for a vertex as first argument the degree on each graph argument, the action fails on wrong input 
[D1|D2]=graph/degree(Vertex,Graph1,Graph2);

math/degrees.name: math/degrees
math/degrees.briefdescription: action for converting angle value to degree value.
math/degrees.detaildescription:
Converts all radian arguments into degree values $ \frac{x_i \cdot 180}{\pi} $ 
A=math/degrees(pi);

math/blas/matrix/determinant.name: math/blas/matrix/determinant
math/blas/matrix/determinant.briefdescription: returns the determinant of a matrix.
math/blas/matrix/determinant.detaildescription:
Calculates for each input matrix the determinat and returns it, the action never fails 
[D1|D2|D3]=math/blas/determinant(M1,[M2,M3]);

math/bit/matrix/dimension.name: math/bit/matrix/dimension
math/bit/matrix/dimension.briefdescription: returns the dimension (rows / columns) of a bit matrix.
math/bit/matrix/dimension.detaildescription:
Reads the dimension of each input matrix and returns the rows and columns, the action never fails. 
[Row1|Column1|Row2|Column2]=math/bit/matrix/dimension(M1,M2);

math/blas/matrix/dimension.name: math/blas/matrix/dimension
math/blas/matrix/dimension.briefdescription: returns the dimension (rows / columns) of a matrix.
math/blas/matrix/dimension.detaildescription:
Reads the dimension of each input matrix and returns the rows and columns, the action never fails. 
[Row1|Column1|Row2|Column2]=math/blas/matrix/dimension(M1,M2);

graph/distancepath.name: graph/distancepath
graph/distancepath.briefdescription: calculates the distance of a route within a graph.
graph/distancepath.detaildescription:
The action calculates the distance based on a cost-edge-map, so the first argument is a map of edges and numeric cost values, the second and third argument are vertices with start- and end-vertex of the route and all other arguments are graph objects, for each graph object a cost value is returned the action fails on wrong input 
[D1|D2]=graph/shortestpath(CostMap,StartVertex,EndVertex,Graph1,Graph2);
note: the cost-map does not need an entry for each edge non-existing edges have got on default zero costs

math/blas/vector/dotproduct.name: math/blas/vector/dotproduct
math/blas/vector/dotproduct.detaildescription:
The action calculates for each tupel of vectors the dot-product, so the argument number must be odd otherwise the action fails 
[D1|D2]=math/blas/vector(V1,V2,[V3,V4]);

graph/edgecount.name: graph/edgecount
graph/edgecount.detaildescription:
The action returns the number of edges within a graph and never fails 
[E1|E2]=graph/edgecount(Graph1,Graph2);

graph/edges.name: graph/edges
graph/edges.briefdescription: returns for a graph all edges.
graph/edges.detaildescription:
The action returns for all graph arguments a list of edges, the action never fails 
[E1|E2]=graph/edges(Graph1,Graph2);
note: the return argument is an unmodifyable list

math/blas/matrix/eigen.name: math/blas/matrix/eigen
math/blas/matrix/eigen.briefdescription: creates the real eigenvalues and eigenvectors of a matrix.
math/blas/matrix/eigen.detaildescription:
For each input matrix argument the eigen decomposition is executed and two elements eigenvalues (as vector) and eigenvectors (as matrix) are returned, the action never fails. 
[Values1|Vectors1|Values2|Vectors2]=math/blas/matrix/eigen(Matrix1,Matrix2);

math/blas/elementwise.name: math/blas/elementwise
math/blas/elementwise.detaildescription:
The action calculates elementwise different operations (plus, plus-absolute, minus, multiply, divide), all arguments are triples of matrix-operator-matrix|scalar, and the operation is assigned to the left-side matrix, the action fails on assigning problems 
math/blas/elementwise(Matrix1,"+",5,Matrix2,"|+|",Matrix3,Matrix4,"-",3,[Matrix5,"*",0.5],[Matrix6,"/",100]);

crypto/encrypt.name: crypto/encrypt
crypto/encrypt.detaildescription:
Encrypts a set of datasets, which can be complex objects, the first argument of the action is the encrypting key and all other arguments are datasets, the action returns all encypted datasets and fails if one encryption fails 
[Encypt1|Encrypt2|Encypt3]=crypto/encrypt(Key,Dataset1,Dataset2,Dataset3);

graph/endpoint.name: graph/endpoint
graph/endpoint.briefdescription: returns of an edge the vertices.
graph/endpoint.detaildescription:
The actions returns for each edge argument the connected vertices, the action fails on wrong input 
[V1|V2|V3|V4]=graph/endpoint(Edge,Graph1,Graph2);

string/endswith.name: string/endswith
string/endswith.briefdescription: action to check string for ends-with.
string/endswith.detaildescription:
The acion checks the string, that is the first argument, with each other arguments for the operation ends-with, the action never fails 
[L1|L2]=generic/string/endswith("thisisalongstring","longstring","string");

bool/equal.name: bool/equal
bool/equal.detaildescription:
The actions checks all tupel of arguments of equality and fails if the unflatten argument number is odd. 
[E1|E2]=generic/bool/equal("thisisequal","thisisequal",[123,"test"]);
note: on number arguments not the value must equal, also the type (double / integral) must be equal, so keep in mind, that you use the correct number type on the argument input

math/linearprogram/equationconstraint.name: math/linearprogram/equationconstraint
math/linearprogram/equationconstraint.briefdescription: add a linear equation constraint to the LP.
math/linearprogram/equationconstraint.detaildescription:
The arguments of the action contains the left and right side of the equation:
  • $ \left( \sum_{i=1} c_i \cdot x_i \right) + c_{const} = \left( \sum_{i=1} r_i \cdot x_i \right) + r_{const} $
  • $ \left( \sum_{i=1} c_i \cdot x_i \right) + c_{const} \geq \left( \sum_{i=1} r_i \cdot x_i \right) + r_{const} $
  • $ \left( \sum_{i=1} c_i \cdot x_i \right) + c_{const} \leq \left( \sum_{i=1} r_i \cdot x_i \right) + r_{const} $
The first arguments is the LP object, the following arguments are the $ c_i $ values, after that the $ c_{const} $ value must be added, in the middle of the arguments the relation symbol ( $ = $, $ \geq $ or $ \leq $) must be set as string, after that all $ r_i $ elements must be set and the last argument is the $ r_{const} $, the action never fails 
math/linearprogram/equationconstraint(LP,[2,7,[7,12,[19]]],"<",[1,2],3,5)
warning: the action throws an exception if the relation symbol is not found

storage/exists.name: storage/exists
storage/exists.briefdescription: check if an element exists within the agent-storage.
storage/exists.detaildescription:
The action checks if an element is within the action and returns the boolean flag, the action never fails 
[A|B]=storage/exist("foo","bar");

math/exp.name: math/exp
math/exp.detaildescription:
Calculate the exponential function $ e^{x_i} $ for each argument, the action never fails 
[X|Y]=math/exp(1,8);

math/statistic/exponentialselection.name: math/statistic/exponentialselection
math/statistic/exponentialselection.briefdescription: action to define a fitness-proportinate-selection mechanism.
math/statistic/exponentialselection.detaildescription:
The action defines a fitness-proportinate-selection based on an exponential distribution, the first and second argument must be a list, the first list contains elements, the second list contains numeric values for defining the weights, the third argument is the demand / rational factor 
S=math/statistic/exponentialselection(["a","b","c","d"],[0.5,0.7,0.9,3],RationalFactor);

math/factorial.name: math/factorial
math/factorial.detaildescription:
Creates the factorial $ ! x_i $ for all unflattern arguments and the action fails never 
[A|B|C|D|E]=math/factorial(5,[[1,2],3,4]);

math/bit/matrix/falsecount.name: math/bit/matrix/falsecount
math/bit/matrix/falsecount.briefdescription: returns the number of false values.
math/bit/matrix/falsecount.detaildescription:
The actions returnf for each input matrix the number of true values, the action never fails 
[A|B]=math/bit/matrix/falsecount(BitMatrix1,BitMatrix2);

math/bit/vector/falsecount.name: math/bit/vector/falsecount
math/bit/vector/falsecount.briefdescription: returns the number of false values.
math/bit/vector/falsecount.detaildescription:
The actions returnf for each input vector the number of true values, the action never fails 
[A|B]=math/bit/vector/falsecount(BitVector1,BitVector2);

graph/findedge.name: graph/findedge
graph/findedge.detaildescription:
The action returns an edge between two vertices, the first two arguments are vertices, all other arguments are graphs, returning values are edges, the action never fails 
[E1|E2|E3]=graph/findedge(Vertex1,Vertex2,Graph1,Graph2,Graph3);

graph/findedgeset.name: graph/findedgeset
graph/findedgeset.briefdescription: returns all edges of two vertices.
graph/findedgeset.detaildescription:
The action returns a list of edges between two vertices, the first two arguments are vertices, all other arguments are graphs and return values are lists, the action never fails 
[L1|L2]=graph/findedgeset(Vertex1,Vertex2,Graph1,Graph2);

collection/tuple/flat.name: collection/tuple/flat
collection/tuple/flat.detaildescription:
All arguments are tupels and each tupel will be extract into two variables, the action never fails 
[A|B|C|D]=collection/tupel/flat(Tupel1,Tupel2);

collection/list/flatconcat.name: collection/list/flatconcat
collection/list/flatconcat.briefdescription: returns a flat concated list of any term data.
collection/list/flatconcat.detaildescription:
The arguments of this action are nested lists and the action transfer all nested structures to a straight list, the action fails never 
F=collection/list/flatconcat([1,2,[3,4]],[[1,2],[7,8]]);

math/floor.name: math/floor
math/floor.detaildescription:
Floors any argument values with $ \lfloor x_i \rfloor $ and returns all values, the action never fails 
[A|B|C]=math/floor(1.3,2.8,9.7);

math/blas/vector/fromlist.name: math/blas/vector/fromlist
math/blas/vector/fromlist.briefdescription: creates a dense- or sparse-vector from a list.
math/blas/vector/fromlist.detaildescription:
All input arguments will be converted to a dense or sparse vector, so the arguments must be lists of numbers, the last optional argument can be a string with "dense | sparse" to create dense or sparse structures, the action never fails 
[V1|V2]=math/blas/vector([1,2,3],[4,5,6],"dense|sparse");

math/geometricmean.name: math/geometricmean
math/geometricmean.detaildescription:
The action calculates $ \sqrt[i]{\prod_{i} x_i} $ over all unflatten arguments, action fails never 
G=math/geometricmean(1,3,9,[10,[11,12]]);

collection/map/get.name: collection/map/get
collection/map/get.briefdescription: returns an element of the map.

math/blas/matrix/get.name: math/blas/matrix/get
math/blas/matrix/get.briefdescription: returns a single element of a matrix.
math/blas/matrix/get.detaildescription:
The action returns single elements of a matrix, the first argument is a matrix object, the other arguments are index tuples and the action never fails 
[A|B]=math/blas/matrix(Matrix,3,4,[Row,Column]);

collection/multimap/get.name: collection/multimap/get
collection/multimap/get.briefdescription: get a element-list of the multimap by key.
collection/multimap/get.detaildescription:
The action can return multiple lists of elements by different keys, one key is needed and the action never failing 
[A|B|C]=collection/multimap/get(Map,"key1","key2",["key3"]);

math/blas/vector/get.name: math/blas/vector/get
math/blas/vector/get.briefdescription: returns a single element of a vector.
math/blas/vector/get.detaildescription:
The action returns the values by the given index, first argument is the vector and all other values are the index values, the action never fails 
[X|Y|Z]=math/blas/vector/get(Vector,1,[4,5]);

collection/list/get.name: collection/list/get
collection/list/get.briefdescription: returns an element of the list by the index.
collection/list/get.detaildescription:
The first argument is a list object and all other arguments are index values, so the action returns the elements, the action fails never 
V=collection/list/get(L,2,7);

agent/getplan.name: agent/getplan
agent/getplan.briefdescription: action to get a plan object.
agent/getplan.detaildescription:
The actions returns a (set of) plan(s), the arguments are tuples of a string with the trigger and a string or literal with the plan definition, for each tuple the plan object will returned, the action fails on non-existing plan 
[A|B]=agent/getplan("+!","myplan(X)","-!",Literal);

math/blas/matrix/graphlaplacian.name: math/blas/matrix/graphlaplacian
math/blas/matrix/graphlaplacian.detaildescription:
For each input matrix, which must be symmetric, the graph laplacian is calculated and returned, the action never fails 
[L1|L2]=math/blas/matrix/graphlaplacian(SymmetricMatrix1,SymmetricMatrix2);

math/bit/matrix/hammingdistance.name: math/bit/matrix/hammingdistance
math/bit/matrix/hammingdistance.detaildescription:
The action calculates between bit matrices, the distance will be calculated between the first and all other arguments, the action never fails 
[A|B]=math/bit/matrix/hammingdistance(Matrix1,Matrix2,Matrix3);

math/bit/vector/hammingdistance.name: math/bit/vector/hammingdistance
math/bit/vector/hammingdistance.detaildescription:
The action calculates between bit vectors, the distance will be calculated between the first and all other arguments, the action never fails 
[A|B]=math/bit/vector/hammingdistance(Vector1,Vector2,Vector3);

math/harmonicmean.name: math/harmonicmean
math/harmonicmean.detaildescription:
The action calculates $ \frac{i}{\sum_{i} \frac{1}{x_i}} $ over all unflatten arguments, action fails never 
G=math/harmonicmean(1,3,9,[10,[11,12]]);

crypto/hash.name: crypto/hash
crypto/hash.detaildescription:
The actions creates a hash values of datasets, the first argument is the name of the hasing algorithm (Adler-32, CRC-32, CRC-32C, Murmur3-32, Murmur3-128, Siphash-2-4, MD2, MD5, SHA-1, SHA-224, SHA-256, SHA-384, SHA-512), for all other arguments a hash value is calculated and the action returns the hash values back, only if the hash algorithm is unknown the action wil fail 
[Hash1|Hash2|Hash3]=crypto/hash("Adler-32|CRC-32|CRC-32C|...",Dataset1,Dataset2,Dataset3);

datetime/hoursbetween.name: datetime/hoursbetween
datetime/hoursbetween.briefdescription: returns the hours between two dates.
datetime/hoursbetween.detaildescription:
The actions returns the number of hours between two date-time objects, the action never fails 
[H1|H2]=datetime/hoursbetween(DateTime1,DateTime2,DateTime3,DateTime4);

math/hypot.name: math/hypot
math/hypot.briefdescription: action for calculating the euclidian length.
math/hypot.detaildescription:
Calculates for each pair of arguments $ \sqrt{ x_{i}^{2} + y_{i}^{2} } $ and fail iif the number of arguments are odd, it unflats all list elements 
[A|B|C]=math/hypot(1,[2,[3]],[4,5]);

graph/incidentcount.name: graph/incidentcount
graph/incidentcount.briefdescription: returns the number of vertices that are incident to edge.
graph/incidentcount.detaildescription:
The action returns the number of verticies that are incident to an edge for each graph object 
[C1|C2]=graph/incidentcount(Edge,Graph1,Graph2);

graph/incidentvertices.name: graph/incidentvertices
graph/incidentvertices.briefdescription: returns a list of incident vertices of an edge.
graph/incidentvertices.detaildescription:
The action returns for the first edge argument the incident vertices in each graph argument, the action never fails 
[L1|L2]=graph/incidentvertices(Edge,Graph1,Graph2);
note: the return argument is an unmodifyable list

math/shape/incircle.name: math/shape/incircle
math/shape/incircle.briefdescription: action check if a point is within a circle.
math/shape/incircle.detaildescription:
The action checks if a point is within a circle, the first three arguments defines the circle (x- / y-position and radius), all other arguments will be used as tuples (x- / y-position) which defines the point, the action fails on wrong input 
[In1|In2]=math/shape/incircle(1,1,1,2,2.5,[3,4]);

graph/indegree.name: graph/indegree
graph/indegree.briefdescription: returns the in-degree of a vertex.
graph/indegree.detaildescription:
The action returns for a vertex as first argument the in-degree on each graph argument, the action fails on wrong input 
[D1|D2]=graph/indegree(Vertex,Graph1,Graph2);

graph/inedges.name: graph/inedges
graph/inedges.briefdescription: returns incomming edges of a vertex.
graph/inedges.detaildescription:
The actions returns a list incoming edges of a vertex for each graph argument, the first argument is the vertex, all other graphs, the action never fails 
[OE1|OE2]=graph/inedges(Vertex,Graph1,Graph2);
note: returned list of edges is unmodifyable

math/blas/matrix/infinitynorm.name: math/blas/matrix/infinitynorm
math/blas/matrix/infinitynorm.briefdescription: returns the infinitiy-norm of a matrix.
math/blas/matrix/infinitynorm.detaildescription:
The action calculates for each input matrix object the infinity-norm and returns the value, the action never fails 
[N1|N2]=math/blas/matrix/infinitynorm(M1,M2);

math/shape/inrectangle.name: math/shape/inrectangle
math/shape/inrectangle.briefdescription: action check if a point within a rectangle.
math/shape/inrectangle.detaildescription:
The first four arguments descripes the rectangle (left-upper corner x- / y-postion, right-bottom corner x- / y-position), all other arguments will used as tuples with x- / y-position and will be checked to the rectangle, the action fail on wrong input 
[In1|In2]=math/shape/inrectangle(10,100,110,10,40,55,120,110);

collection/list/intersect.name: collection/list/intersect
collection/list/intersect.detaildescription:
All arguments are lists and the action returns the intersection $ \cap M_i \forall i \in \mathbb{N} $, the action fails never 
I=collection/list/intersect([1,2,[3,4]],[3,4,[8,9]],[1,2,3,5]);

math/shape/intriangle.name: math/shape/intriangle
math/shape/intriangle.briefdescription: action check if a point is within a triangle.
math/shape/intriangle.detaildescription:
The first three tuple of arguments defines the triangle coordinate (x- / y-position), all other tuples are the tuples of x- / y-position, the action fails on wrong input 
[In1|In2]=math/shape/intriangle([[350,320],[25,375],40,55],[160,270],0,0);

math/blas/matrix/invert.name: math/blas/matrix/invert
math/blas/matrix/invert.detaildescription:
Inverts each input matrix and returns it, the action never fails 
[I1|I2]=math/blas/matrix/invert(M1,M2);

generic/type/is.name: generic/type/is
generic/type/is.briefdescription: action to check if a type is a class.
generic/type/is.detaildescription:
The action checks the type of a value if it is assignable to a class type, the first argument is the value, all other values are strings witha full-qualified class name, the action returns for each class name a boolean if it is assignable, the action never fails 
[A|B|C|D]=generic/type(X,"java.lang.String","java.lang.Number","java.lang.Double","java.lang.Long");

collection/list/isempty.name: collection/list/isempty
collection/list/isempty.detaildescription:
Concats all list arguments (and removes the nested structures) and returns a boolean of the empty check, the action fails never 
E=collection/list/isempty([]);

graph/isincident.name: graph/isincident
graph/isincident.briefdescription: checks if a vertex and an edge incident.
graph/isincident.detaildescription:
The actions checks for the first vertex argument and the second egde argument if both are incident within all graphs 
[B1|B2]=graph/isincident(Vertex,Edge,Graph1,Graph2);

graph/isneighbor.name: graph/isneighbor
graph/isneighbor.briefdescription: checks if a vertex is predecessor of another vertex.
graph/isneighbor.detaildescription:
The action checks for the first vertex argument that the second vertex argument is predecessor within the given graph, the action never fails 
[B1|B2|B3]=graph/isneighbor(Vertex1,Vertex2,Graph1,Graph2,Graph3);

generic/type/isnull.name: generic/type/isnull
generic/type/isnull.briefdescription: action to check if a value is a null value.
generic/type/isnull.detaildescription:
The actions checks all arguments if the values are null, the action never fails and returns booleans 
[A|B]=generic/type(X,Y);

generic/type/isnumeric.name: generic/type/isnumeric
generic/type/isnumeric.briefdescription: action to check if a type is a number.
generic/type/isnumeric.detaildescription:
The actions checks all arguments for a number value and it fails if one of the arguments not a number 
generic/type/isnumeric(X,3.5);

graph/ispredecessor.name: graph/ispredecessor
graph/ispredecessor.briefdescription: checks if a vertex is predecessor of another vertex.
graph/ispredecessor.detaildescription:
The action checks for the first vertex argument that the second vertex argument is predecessor within the given graph, the action never fails 
[B1|B2|B3]=graph/ispredecessor(Vertex1,Vertex2,Graph1,Graph2,Graph3);

math/isprime.name: math/isprime
math/isprime.briefdescription: action for checking for a prime number.
math/isprime.detaildescription:
Checks for all unflatten arguments if the number is a prime number and returns a boolean of this check, the actions never fails 
[P1|P2]=math/isprime(3,4);

generic/type/isstring.name: generic/type/isstring
generic/type/isstring.briefdescription: action to check if a type is a string.
generic/type/isstring.detaildescription:
All arguments are check if it is a string, the action fails if one of the arguments are not a string 
generic/type/isstring("foo","bar");

graph/issuccessor.name: graph/issuccessor
graph/issuccessor.briefdescription: checks if a vertex is successor of another vertex.
graph/issuccessor.detaildescription:
The action checks for the first vertex argument that the second vertex argument is successor within the given graph, the action never fails 
[B1|B2|B3]=graph/issuccessor(Vertex1,Vertex2,Graph1,Graph2,Graph3);

rest/jsonlist.name: rest/jsonlist
rest/jsonlist.briefdescription: action for calling a restful webservice with a JSON object list.
rest/jsonlist.detaildescription:
Creates a literal based on an JSON webservice data, the first argument is the URL of the webservice, all other arguments are the literal elements of the returning literal, the webservice must return a JSON list and the last argument will used to encapsulate the list elements 
W=rest/jsonlist("https://api.github.com/repos/LightJason/AgentSpeak/commits","github","elements");

rest/jsonobject.name: rest/jsonobject
rest/jsonobject.briefdescription: action for calling a restful webservice with a JSON object.
rest/jsonobject.detaildescription:
Creates a literal based on an JSON webservice data, the first argument is the URL of the webservice, all other arguments are the literal elements of the returning literal, the webservice must return a JSON object 
W=rest/jsonobject("https://maps.googleapis.com/maps/api/geocode/json?address=Clausthal-Zellerfeld","google","location");

collection/map/keys.name: collection/map/keys
collection/map/keys.briefdescription: returns all key values of the map.
collection/map/keys.detaildescription:
Returns a unique list with all key values of the argument maps and fails never, all arguments must be maps 
L=collection/map/keys(Map1,Map2,Map3);

collection/multimap/keys.name: collection/multimap/keys
collection/multimap/keys.briefdescription: returns all key values of the multimap.
collection/multimap/keys.detaildescription:
Returns a unique list with all key values of the argument maps and fails never, all arguments must be multimaps 
L=collection/map/keys(MultiMap1,MultiMap2,MultiMap3);

string/levenshtein.name: string/levenshtein
string/levenshtein.detaildescription:
The action returns the levenshtein distance between string inputs, for the first string argument the distance will be calculated to the rest, if there are numerical arguments the first will be used for the inserting weight, second replace weight and third for the delete weight, the action fails on wrong input 
[A|B]=string/levenshtein(1,1.5,3,"start","end","starting");

math/statistic/linearselection.name: math/statistic/linearselection
math/statistic/linearselection.briefdescription: action to define a exponential fitness-proportinate-selection mechanism.
math/statistic/linearselection.detaildescription:
The action defines a fitness-proportinate-selection based on a linear distribution, the first and second argument must be a list, the first list contains elements, the second list contains numeric values for defining the weights 
S=math/statistic/linearselection(RationalFactor,["a","b","c","d"],[0.5,0.7,0.9,3]);

math/log.name: math/log
math/log.detaildescription:
Calculates the natural logarithm $ log( x_i ) $ for each unflatten argument 
[A|B|C]=math/log([1,2],3);

math/log10.name: math/log10
math/log10.detaildescription:
Calculates the logarithm of the base 10 $ log_{10} x_i $ for all unflatten arguments 
[A|B|C]=math/log10([1,2],3);

string/lower.name: string/lower
string/lower.briefdescription: action to create a lower-case string.
string/lower.detaildescription:
All arguments of the action will change to a lower-case string and the action never fails 
[A|B|C|D]=generic/string/lower("AbC","Ef",["de","XyZ"]);

math/blas/matrix/matrixnorm.name: math/blas/matrix/matrixnorm
math/blas/matrix/matrixnorm.briefdescription: returns the frobenius- / matrix-norm of a matrix.
math/blas/matrix/matrixnorm.detaildescription:
For each input matrix object the frobenius- / matrix-norm is calculates and returned, the action never fails 
[N1|N2]=math/blas/matrix/matrixnorm(M1,M2);

math/max.name: math/max
math/max.detaildescription:
The action calculates for all unflatten arguments the maxmimum with $ max( x_0, x_1, \ldots, x_i ) $, the action never fails 
Max=math/max(2,5,7,[3,2]);

math/maxindex.name: math/maxindex
math/maxindex.detaildescription:
The action takes of the given unflatten input the maximum and returns the index within the unflatten argument list, the action never fails 
MaxIndex=math/maxindex(5,6,[7,8,[1,2,3]]);

math/min.name: math/min
math/min.detaildescription:
The action calculates for all unflatten arguments the minimum with $ min( x_0, x_1, \ldots, x_i ) $, the action never fails 
Max=math/min(2,5,7,[3,2]);

math/minindex.name: math/minindex
math/minindex.detaildescription:
The action takes of the given unflatten input the minimum and returns the index within the unflatten argument list, the action never fails 
MinIndex=math/minindex(5,6,[7,8,[1,2,3]]);

datetime/minutesbetween.name: datetime/minutesbetween
datetime/minutesbetween.briefdescription: returns the minutes between two dates.
datetime/minutesbetween.detaildescription:
The actions returns the number of minutes between two date-time objects, the action never fails 
[M1|M2]=datetime/minutesbetween(DateTime1,DateTime2,DateTime3,DateTime4);

datetime/monthsbetween.name: datetime/monthsbetween
datetime/monthsbetween.briefdescription: returns the months between two dates.
datetime/monthsbetween.detaildescription:
The actions returns the number of months between two date-time objects, the action never fails 
[M1|M2]=datetime/monthsbetween(DateTime1,DateTime2,DateTime3,DateTime4);

math/interpolate/multipleinterpolate.name: math/interpolate/multipleinterpolate
math/interpolate/multipleinterpolate.detaildescription:
The action interpolates a single value, the first argument is the value (x-position), all other interpolating functions, the action never fails interpolation 
[A|B|C]=math/interpolate/multipleinterpolate(5,InterpolatingFunction1,[InterpolatingFunction2,[InterpolatingFunction3]]);

math/statistic/multiplestatisticvalue.name: math/statistic/multiplestatisticvalue
math/statistic/multiplestatisticvalue.briefdescription: gets multiple statistic values of a single statistic object.
math/statistic/multiplestatisticvalue.detaildescription:
The action returns different statistic values from a single statistic object, the first argument is the statistic object, all other values are string with statistic value names: geometricmean, max, min, count, populationvariance, quadraticmean, secondmoment, standarddeviation, sum, sumlog, sumsquare, variance, mean, kurtiosis 
[SStd|SVar|SMean]=math/statistic/multiplestatisticvalue(Statistic,"standarddeviation","variance","mean");

math/blas/multiply.name: math/blas/multiply
math/blas/multiply.detaildescription:
The action multiplies tupel-wise all unflatten arguments, the action fails iif the multiply cannot executed e.g. on wrong input 
[M1|M2|M3]=math/blas/multiply(Vector1,Vector2,[[Matrix1,Matrix2],Matrix3,Vector3]);

math/bit/matrix/nand.name: math/bit/matrix/nand
math/bit/matrix/nand.briefdescription: performs the logical not-and operation to all bit matrices.
math/bit/matrix/nand.detaildescription:
The action runs the logical not-and operator, the first argument is the bit matrix, that is combined with all other bit matrices, so $ m_i = m_i \text{ && not } m_1 $ is performed, the action never fails 
math/bit/matrix/nand(Matrix,Matrix1,Matrix2);

math/bit/vector/nand.name: math/bit/vector/nand
math/bit/vector/nand.briefdescription: performs the logical not-and operation to all bit vectors.
math/bit/vector/nand.detaildescription:
The action runs the logical not-and operator, the first argument is the bit vector, that is combined with all other bit vectors, so $ v_i = v_i \text{ && not } v_1 $ is performed, the action never fails 
math/bit/vector/nand(Vector,Vector1,Vector2);

string/ncd.name: string/ncd
string/ncd.detaildescription:
The action calculates the normalized-compression-distance between string, if the first argument matches a compression algorithm ( BZIP | GZIP | DEFLATE | PACK200 | XZ ), it will be used for defining the compression, the next string argument will be the input string and the distances will be calculated between the first and all other arguments, the action fails on wrong input 
[A|B]=string/ncd("BZIP|GZIP|DEFLATE|PACK200|XZ","foobar","testfoo","barfoo");

graph/neighbors.name: graph/neighbors
graph/neighbors.briefdescription: returns the neighbors of a vertex.
graph/neighbors.detaildescription:
The actions returns a list of neighbors of a vertex for each graph argument, the first argument is the vertex, all other graphs, the action never fails 
[N1|N2]=graph/neighbors(Vertex,Graph1,Graph2);
note: returned list of neighbors is unmodifyable

graph/neighborscount.name: graph/neighborscount
graph/neighborscount.briefdescription: returns the number neighbors of a vertex.
graph/neighborscount.detaildescription:
The actions returns the number of neighbors of a vertex for each graph argument, the first argument is the vertex, all other graphs, the action never fails 
[C1|C2]=graph/neighborscount(Vertex,Graph1,Graph2);

math/nextprime.name: math/nextprime
math/nextprime.briefdescription: action for create the next prime number.
math/nextprime.detaildescription:
The action calculates the next prime number relative to the given argument value, the action never fails 
[A|B|C]=math/nextprime([12,[144,1096]]);

math/blas/matrix/nonzero.name: math/blas/matrix/nonzero
math/blas/matrix/nonzero.briefdescription: returns the number of non-zero cells.
math/blas/matrix/nonzero.detaildescription:
Gets the number of non-zero cells on each matrix input and returns the value, the action never fails 
[NZ1|NZ2]=math/blas/matrix/nonzero(M1,M2);

math/blas/vector/nonzero.name: math/blas/vector/nonzero
math/blas/vector/nonzero.briefdescription: returns the number of non-zero cells.
math/blas/vector/nonzero.detaildescription:
Gets the number of non-zero cells on each vector input and returns the value, the action never fails 
[NZ1|NZ2]=math/blas/vector/nonzero(V1,V2);

math/blas/matrix/normalizedgraphlaplacia.name: math/blas/matrix/normalizedgraphlaplacian
math/blas/matrix/normalizedgraphlaplacia.detaildescription:
For each input matrix, which must be symmetric, the normalized graph laplacian is calculated and returned, the action never fails 
[L1|L2]=math/blas/matrix/normalizedgraphlaplacian(SymmetricMatrix1,SymmetricMatrix2);

math/bit/matrix/not.name: math/bit/matrix/not
math/bit/matrix/not.briefdescription: performs the logical not operation to all bit matrices.
math/bit/matrix/not.detaildescription:
Each input argument defines a bit matrix and the action apply the logical not operator, the action never fails 
math/bit/matrix/not(Matrix1,Matrix2);

math/bit/vector/not.name: math/bit/vector/not
math/bit/vector/not.briefdescription: performs the logical not operation to all bit vectors.
math/bit/vector/not.detaildescription:
Each input argument defines a bit vector and the action apply the logical not operator, the action never fails 
math/bit/vector/not(Vector1,Vector2);

bool/not.name: bool/not
bool/not.detaildescription:
This action uses the logical negation and inverts all logical boolean arguments and returns all elements, the action never fails 
[R1|R2|R3|R4]=generic/bool/not(Logical1,[Logical2,Logical3],Logical4);

bool/notequal.name: bool/notequal
bool/notequal.detaildescription:
The actions checks all tupel of arguments of inequality and fails if the unflatten argument number is odd. 
[NE1|NE2]=generic/bool/notequal("thisisequal","thisisequal",[123,"test"]);
note: on number arguments not the value must equal, also the type (double / integral) must be equal, so keep in mind, that you use the correct number type on the argument input

math/bit/matrix/numericvalue.name: math/bit/matrix/numericvalue
math/bit/matrix/numericvalue.briefdescription: returns for the index tuple a numeric value.
math/bit/matrix/numericvalue.detaildescription:
The action returns for the first argument, which is a bit matrix, all numeric values for all given index tuples (0 = false, 1 = true), the action fails on wrong input 
[B1|B2]=math/bit/matrix/numericvalue(BitMatrix,1,2,[Row,Column]);

math/bit/vector/numericvalue.name: math/bit/vector/numericvalue
math/bit/vector/numericvalue.briefdescription: returns for the index a numeric value.
math/bit/vector/numericvalue.detaildescription:
The action returns for the first argument, which is a bit vector, all numeric values for all given index values (0 = false, 1 = true), the action never fails 
[B1|B2|B3]=math/bit/vector/numericvalue(BitVector,1,[3,5]);

math/blas/matrix/onenorm.name: math/blas/matrix/onenorm
math/blas/matrix/onenorm.briefdescription: returns the one-norm of a matrix.
math/blas/matrix/onenorm.detaildescription:
Calculates for each input matrix the one-norm and returns the value, the action never fails 
[N1|N2]=math/blas/matrix/onenorm(M1,M2);

graph/opposite.name: graph/opposite
graph/opposite.briefdescription: returns the opposit of a vertex and edge.
graph/opposite.detaildescription:
The action returns the opposite vertex, with the first argument is a vertex, the second an edge an all other arguments are graphs, the action never fails 
[V1|V2]=graph/opposite(Vertex,Edge,Graph1,Graph2);

math/bit/matrix/or.name: math/bit/matrix/or
math/bit/matrix/or.briefdescription: performs the logical or operation to all bit matrices.
math/bit/matrix/or.detaildescription:
The action runs the logical or operator, the first argument is the bit matrix, that is combined with all other bit matrices, so $ m_i = m_i \text{ || } m_1 $ is performed, the action never fails 
math/bit/matrix/or(Matrix,Matrix1,Matrix2);

math/bit/vector/or.name: math/bit/vector/or
math/bit/vector/or.briefdescription: performs the logical or operation to all bit vectors.
math/bit/vector/or.detaildescription:
The action runs the logical or operator, the first argument is the bit vector, that is combined with all other bit vectors, so $ v_i = v_i \text{ || } v_1 $ is performed, the action never fails 
math/bit/vector/or(Vector,Vector1,Vector2);

bool/or.name: bool/or
bool/or.briefdescription: combines all arguments to a single result with the or-operator.
bool/or.detaildescription:
This action uses the logical disjunction to combine all logical arguments in a single result, the action never fails 
R=generic/bool/or(Logical1,[Logical2,Logical3],Logical4);

graph/outdegree.name: graph/outdegree
graph/outdegree.briefdescription: returns the out-degree of a vertex.
graph/outdegree.detaildescription:
The action returns for a vertex as first argument the out-degree on each graph argument, the action fails on wrong input 
[D1|D2]=graph/outdegree(Vertex,Graph1,Graph2);

graph/outedges.name: graph/outedges
graph/outedges.briefdescription: returns outgoing edges of a vertex.
graph/outedges.detaildescription:
The actions returns a list outgoing edges of a vertex for each graph argument, the first argument is the vertex, all other graphs, the action never fails 
[OE1|OE2]=graph/outedges(Vertex,Graph1,Graph2);
note: returned list of edges is unmodifyable

math/blas/matrix/parse.name: math/blas/matrix/parse
math/blas/matrix/parse.briefdescription: creates a dense- or sparse-matrix from a string.
math/blas/matrix/parse.detaildescription:
The action parses each argument and returns the matrix object, the last argument can be a string with "dense" or "sparse" to defining a dense or sparse matrix, all other arguments string with a semicolon and space / comma seperated list, the action never fails 
[A|B|C]=math/blas/matrix/parse("1,2;3,4","567;8910","dense|sparse")
note: semicolon splits the rows, spaces / comma splits the columns

generic/type/parsefloat.name: generic/type/parsefloat
generic/type/parsefloat.briefdescription: action for parsing a float from string.
generic/type/parsefloat.detaildescription:
Parses each argument to a floating point value and returns the value, the action fails on parsing errors 
[X|Y|Z]=generic/type/parsefloat("1.45",["8.88","9"]);

generic/type/parseint.name: generic/type/parseint
generic/type/parseint.briefdescription: action for parsing a integer from string.
generic/type/parseint.detaildescription:
Parses each argument to a integer point value and returns the value, the action fails on parsing errors 
[X|Y|Z]=generic/type/parseint("1",["3","9"]);

generic/type/parseliteral.name: generic/type/parseliteral
generic/type/parseliteral.briefdescription: action for parsing a integer from string.
generic/type/parseliteral.detaildescription:
Parses each argument to a integer point value and returns the value, the action fails on parsing errors 
[X|Y|Z]=generic/type/parseliteral("foo(5)",["bar(foo('abcd')","xxx()[source(3)]"]);

agent/planlist.name: agent/planlist
agent/planlist.briefdescription: action to get plan-information as list.
agent/planlist.detaildescription:
The action returns a list of tuples with the a string (trigger definition) and the plan literal, the action never fails 
L=agent/planlist();

agent/planstatistic.name: agent/planstatistic
agent/planstatistic.detaildescription:
The actions returns for each plan the statistic information, for each plan argument, succesfull, fail and sum rate is returned, the action fails if the plan does not exist within the plan-base 
[Successful1|Fail1|Sum1|Successful2|Fail2|Sum2]=agent/planstatistic(Plan1,Plan2);

math/pow.name: math/pow
math/pow.detaildescription:
Calculates the pow for each unflatten argument $ x_i^t $, the first argument is the exponent t and all other arguments will be used for $ x_i $, the action fails never 
[A|B|C]=math/pow(2,-2,2,9);

math/blas/matrix/power.name: math/blas/matrix/power
math/blas/matrix/power.detaildescription:
The action creates the matrix power, the first argument is the exponent, all other arguments are input matrix vlaues and the returns the power value for each input matrix 
[M1|M2|M3]=blas/matrix/power(3,M1,[M2,[M3]]);

graph/predecessorcount.name: graph/predecessorcount
graph/predecessorcount.briefdescription: returns the number of predecessors within a graph.
graph/predecessorcount.detaildescription:
The action returns for the first vertex argument the number of predecessors on all other graph arguments, the action never fails 
[C1|C2]=graph/predecessorcount(Vertex,Graph1,Graph2);

math/primefactors.name: math/primefactors
math/primefactors.briefdescription: action for creating prime factors list.
math/primefactors.detaildescription:
For each argument the action returns a list of prime factors and fails never. 
[L1|L2]=math/primfactors(8,[120]);

generic/print.name: generic/print
generic/print.detaildescription:
Prints a set of messages to the commandline / output-stream, the command can be used with a variable set of arguments and fails never 
generic/print("stringA=",A,"--B=",B,"--C=",C,"--D=",D,"--X=",X,"--Y=",Y);

collection/map/put.name: collection/map/put
collection/map/put.briefdescription: adds an element to all map arguments.
collection/map/put.detaildescription:
First argument is a key value, second the value, all other values are map references, the key-value pair is added and the action never fails 
collection/map/put("key","value",Map1,Map2);

collection/multimap/put.name: collection/multimap/put
collection/multimap/put.briefdescription: adds an element to all map arguments.
collection/multimap/put.detaildescription:
First argument is a key value, second the value, all other values are map references, the key-value pair is added and the action never fails 
collection/map/put("key","value",MultiMap1,MultiMap2);

collection/map/putifabsent.name: collection/map/putifabsent
collection/map/putifabsent.briefdescription: adds an element to all map arguments iif not exists.
collection/map/putifabsent.detaildescription:
First argument is a key value, second the value, all other values are map references, the key-value pair is added iif not exists and the action never fails 
collection/map/putifabsent("key","value",Map1,Map2);

math/radians.name: math/radians
math/radians.briefdescription: action for converting degree value into radian.
math/radians.detaildescription:
Converts all degree arguments into radian values $ \frac{x_i \cdot \pi}{180} $ 
A=math/radians(180);

string/random.name: string/random
string/random.briefdescription: action to create random strings, with a definied length.
string/random.detaildescription:
The first argument are the characters, that will be used to create the string, all other arguments are numbers to present the length of the returning string and the action never fails 
[A|B|C]=generic/string/random("abdefgXYZUI",5,3,6);

math/statistic/randomsample.name: math/statistic/randomsample
math/statistic/randomsample.detaildescription:
The action creates a set or single random value based on a distirbution, the first argument is the distirbution and all other arguments defines the size of the samples 
[R1|R2]=math/statistic/randomsample(Distribution,1,5);

math/statistic/randomsimple.name: math/statistic/randomsimple
math/statistic/randomsimple.briefdescription: create a (set) of simple random values.
math/statistic/randomsimple.detaildescription:
Returns single or a list of random (uniform distributed) values, all arguments are the number of returning values, if the argument number is 1 a single random value is returned, is the number greater than 1 a list of values is returned 
[V1|L1|V2|L2]=math/statistic/randomsimple(1,5,1,10);

collection/list/range.name: collection/list/range
collection/list/range.briefdescription: creates a list with a integer ranged list.
collection/list/range.detaildescription:
Creates a list of integer values within the range $ [\text{argument 1}, \text{argument 2}) $, the action fails never 
L=collection/list/create(0,10);

math/bit/vector/range.name: math/bit/vector/range
math/bit/vector/range.briefdescription: returns a new bit vector, based on the current.
math/bit/vector/range.detaildescription:
The action returns a new bit vector based on the range, the first argument is a bit vector, all other arguments are tuples of ranges, the action fails on wrong input, index starts at zero, the action never fails 
[V1|V2]=math/bit/vector/range(BitVector,0,1,[3,5]);

math/blas/matrix/rank.name: math/blas/matrix/rank
math/blas/matrix/rank.detaildescription:
For each input matrix the rank is calculated and returned, the action never fails 
[R1|R2]=math/blas/matrix/rank(M1,M2);

collection/list/remove.name: collection/list/remove
collection/list/remove.briefdescription: returns an element of the list by the index.
collection/list/remove.detaildescription:
Removes an element by the list index, the first argument is the list object, the second argument is the index, the action fails never 
collection/list/remove(L,3);

storage/remove.name: storage/remove
storage/remove.briefdescription: removes an element by name from the storage.
storage/remove.detaildescription:
The actions removes any value from the storage which is referenced by the key and returns the value, the action fails on forbidden key or non exisiting elements 
[A|B]=storage/remove("foo","bar");

collection/map/remove.name: collection/map/remove
collection/map/remove.detaildescription:
Removes of possible all arguments from the map, first argument is the map reference all other arguments are key values returns the arguments (or null if not exists) and never fails 
[A|B|C]=collection/map/remove(Map,"a",12,"c");

graph/removeedge.name: graph/removeedge
graph/removeedge.detaildescription:
The action removes edges from a graph, the first argument is the graph all other arguments are edges, fails if an edge cannot removed 
graph/removeedge(Graph,Edge1,Edge2);

agent/removeplan.name: agent/removeplan
agent/removeplan.briefdescription: removes a plan by the plan trigger.
agent/removeplan.detaildescription:
The action moves all plan based on the input trigger arguments, the action fails on wrong input 
agent/removeplan("+!","myplan(X)","-!",Literal);

graph/removevertex.name: graph/removevertex
graph/removevertex.detaildescription:
The action removes vertices from a graph, the first argument is the graph all other arguments are vertices, fails if a vertex cannot removed 
graph/removevertex(Graph,Vertex1,Vertex2);

string/replace.name: string/replace
string/replace.briefdescription: action to replace all occurence within a string.
string/replace.detaildescription:
The action replaces the first argument with the second argument on each string beginning at the third argument and returns all replaced strings, the action never fails 
[A|B]=string/replace("search","replacewith","thisisasearchstring","thisisanotherstring");
note: the first argument of the action be defined as a regular expression

collection/list/reverse.name: collection/list/reverse
collection/list/reverse.detaildescription:
All arguments of the action are lists and the action will remove nested structures and reverse all elements in a single list, the action fails never 
R=collection/list/reverse(L,[1,2],[3,4,[7,8]]);

string/reverse.name: string/reverse
string/reverse.detaildescription:
The action reverse each argument string and returns the reversed string, the action never fails 
[A|B|C]=generic/string/reverse("FooBar",["ABBA","Eevee"]);

math/round.name: math/round
math/round.detaildescription:
This action calculates for each unflatten input argument the rounded value and the action fails never 
[I1|I2|I3]=math/round(5.5,[1.2,[2.7]]);

math/bit/matrix/row.name: math/bit/matrix/row
math/bit/matrix/row.briefdescription: returns a single row of a bit matrix.
math/bit/matrix/row.detaildescription:
The action returns a row of a matrix as vector, the first argument is the index of the row, all other arguments are matrix object, the action never fails 
[R1|R2]=math/bit/matrix/row(2,Matrix1,[Matrix2]);

math/blas/matrix/row.name: math/blas/matrix/row
math/blas/matrix/row.briefdescription: returns a single row of a matrix.
math/blas/matrix/row.detaildescription:
The action returns a row of a matrix as vector, the first argument is the index of the row, all other arguments are matrix object, the action never fails 
[R1|R2]=math/blas/matrix/row(2,Matrix1,[Matrix2]);

math/bit/matrix/rows.name: math/bit/matrix/rows
math/bit/matrix/rows.briefdescription: returns the row number of a matrix.
math/bit/matrix/rows.detaildescription:
Reads the row number of each input matrix and returns the value, the action never fails. 
[C1|C2]=math/blas/matrix/rows(M1,M2);

math/blas/matrix/rows.name: math/blas/matrix/rows
math/blas/matrix/rows.briefdescription: returns the row number of a matrix.
math/blas/matrix/rows.detaildescription:
Reads the row number of each input matrix and returns the value, the action never fails. 
[C1|C2]=math/blas/matrix/rows(M1,M2);

datetime/secondsbetween.name: datetime/secondsbetween
datetime/secondsbetween.briefdescription: returns the seconds between two dates.
datetime/secondsbetween.detaildescription:
The actions returns the number of seconds between two date-time objects, the action never fails 
[S1|S2]=datetime/secondsbetween(DateTime1,DateTime2,DateTime3,DateTime4);

collection/list/set.name: collection/list/set
collection/list/set.briefdescription: adds an element to the list.
collection/list/set.detaildescription:
Sets an element within the list by index, the first argument is the list object, the second the index value and third the new value of the element, the action fails never 
collection/list/set(L,2,"astringvalue");

math/bit/vector/set.name: math/bit/vector/set
math/bit/vector/set.briefdescription: sets bit position by index and value.
math/bit/vector/set.detaildescription:
The first argument is the bit vector, the second argument is a boolean value or number value (0 = false), all other values are index positions, each index bit within the bit vector will be set to the given value, the action never fails 
math/bit/vector/set(BitVector,true,1,[3,7]);

math/blas/matrix/set.name: math/blas/matrix/set
math/blas/matrix/set.briefdescription: set a single element of a matrix.
math/blas/matrix/set.detaildescription:
The action sets a value into the matrix, the first argument is the row index, second argument the column index, the third value, the new value, all other arguments are matrix objects 
math/blas/matrix/set(2,2,0.33,Matrix1,[Matrix2,Matrix3]);

math/blas/vector/set.name: math/blas/vector/set
math/blas/vector/set.briefdescription: set a single element of a vector.
math/blas/vector/set.detaildescription:
The first argument is the index, the second argument the value and all other arguments are vector objects, the action never fails 
math/blas/vector/assign(3,5.3,Vector1,[Vector2,[Vector3]]);

graph/shortestpath.name: graph/shortestpath
graph/shortestpath.briefdescription: calculates the shortest path of two vertices within graph.
graph/shortestpath.detaildescription:
The action calculates a path based on a cost-edge-map, so the first argument is a map of edges and numeric cost values, the second and third argument are vertices with start- and end-vertex of the route and all other arguments are graph objects, for each graph object a list of vertices of the route is returned, the action fails on wrong input 
[Route1|Route2]=graph/shortestpath(CostMap,StartVertex,EndVertex,Graph1,Graph2);
note: the cost-map does not need an entry for each edge non-existing edges have got on default zero costs

math/sigmoid.name: math/sigmoid
math/sigmoid.briefdescription: action for calculating a parameterized sigmoid function.
math/sigmoid.detaildescription:
Action calculates the sigmoid function for each value, the definition of the function is $ \frac{\alpha}{ \beta + e^{ - \gamma \cdot t }} $$ \alpha $ is the first, $ \beta $ the second and $ \gamma $ the third argument, all values beginning at the fourth position will be used for t, so the action returns all values but and is never failing. 
[A|B|C]=math/sigmoid(1,1,1,10,20,30);

math/signum.name: math/signum
math/signum.detaildescription:
Calculates for each argument the signum value $ sgn(x) = \begin{cases} -1 & \text{if } x < 0 \\ 0 & \text{if } x = 0 \\ 1 & \text{if } x > 0 \end{cases} $ 
[A|B|C]=math/signum(-3,0,8)

math/sin.name: math/sin
math/sin.detaildescription:
The action calculates $ sin( x_i ) $ for each argument in radians and returns the values 
[A|B]=math/sin(3,4);

math/interpolate/singleinterpolate.name: math/interpolate/singleinterpolate
math/interpolate/singleinterpolate.detaildescription:
The action interpolates values, the first argument is the interpolating function, all other number values (x-position) for interpolation 
[A|B|C]=math/interpolate/singleinterpolate(InterpolatingFunction,3,[10,[50]]);

math/statistic/singlestatisticvalue.name: math/statistic/singlestatisticvalue
math/statistic/singlestatisticvalue.briefdescription: gets a single statistic value of multiple statistic objects.
